steps.title: See your doctor if you suspect your iron levels are low.
steps.content: See your doctor if you suspect your iron levels are low. Your doctor is the best way to get your iron levels checked. Make an appointment to see your doctor within 1-2 weeks if you're showing basic signs of anemia like fatigue. The first step the doctor will take is to ask you about any history you've had with low iron in the past. Then, the doctor will ask you questions about your recent symptoms and health. [1] X Trustworthy Source National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Research and education center within the National Institutes of Health Go to source If you are having heart palpitations or shortness of breath, go immediately to urgent care or the emergency room. If you're having chest pains and breathing problems together, go straight to the emergency room. Your doctor may ask you about your diet. For women, they may also ask if you've had a heavy period recently. It can help to write down any symptoms you've been experiencing before you head to the doctor. That way, you won't forget when you get to the exam room.

steps.title: Expect a physical exam.
steps.content: Expect a physical exam. The doctor will do things like look at your mouth, skin, and nail beds, listen to your heart and lungs, and feel your abdominal area. They will be checking for signs of low or high iron. [2] X Trustworthy Source National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Research and education center within the National Institutes of Health Go to source Some signs of low iron may include fatigue, shortness of breath, dizziness, coldness in your extremities, pale skin, slowed appetite, and cravings for non-food items (known as pica). Let your doctor know if you have experienced any of these. [3] X Trustworthy Source National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Research and education center within the National Institutes of Health Go to source Other physical signs your doctor may look for include brittle nails, a swollen tongue, cracks in the sides of the mouth, and frequent infections.

steps.title: Be ready for a blood test.
steps.content: Be ready for a blood test. The doctor will order blood tests if they suspect your iron levels aren't right. [4] X Expert Source Kristi Acuna Holistic Nutritionist Expert Interview. 17 September 2020. The doctor may use more than one type of blood test to check to see whether your iron levels are high or low. [5] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Usually, you'll get results between 1-3 days after you had the blood test. These tests will give your doctor an idea of your hemoglobin levels. These levels measure how much oxygen is binding with your red blood cells. Your doctor might also recommend a nutrition response test to see if your body needs iron. [6] X Expert Source Kristi Acuna Holistic Nutritionist Expert Interview. 17 September 2020.

steps.title: Find a place where you can donate blood.
steps.content: Find a place where you can donate blood. Check the websites of blood donation organizations to find out where you can donate. For instance, you can use the American Red Cross website to look for blood donation centers in your area. Alternatively, watch for blood drives where you can give blood. The American Red Cross states that it administers the hemoglobin test on its website. Check to make sure the organization you're donating with also provides this test. Most organizations screen for low or high iron levels.

steps.title: Go in to donate blood.
steps.content: Go in to donate blood . This method requires that you be willing to donate blood, as the test is part of the donation process. Usually, you can just show up to donate--you don't need to make an appointment. However, you do need to be healthy. You also need to be at least 17-years-old and weigh a minimum of 110 pounds. [7] X Trustworthy Source Red Cross Blood Donation Services Website run by the Red Cross Organization providing information about how and where to donate blood safely Go to source For donating blood, "healthy" means you are able to perform your usual routine, and you have any chronic disease, such as diabetes, under control. It also means that you don't have an infection like a cold or the flu, or certain illnesses including malaria, syphilis, and HIV/AIDS.

steps.title: Expect a finger prick.
steps.content: Expect a finger prick. Before you give blood, the technician will stick your finger using a fingerstick, which just means they poke your finger with a small, spring-loaded needle. That will produce a drop of blood the technician can use to check your hemoglobin levels. [8] X Trustworthy Source Red Cross Blood Donation Services Website run by the Red Cross Organization providing information about how and where to donate blood safely Go to source

steps.title: Ask about your hemoglobin level.
steps.content: Ask about your hemoglobin level. The technician likely won't give you an exact figure. However, this test is used to screen you for high or low hemoglobin, which can indicate high and low iron. Therefore, if you're disqualified from giving blood, you can ask if it was your hemoglobin level and whether the level was in the high or low range. [9] X Trustworthy Source Red Cross Blood Donation Services Website run by the Red Cross Organization providing information about how and where to donate blood safely Go to source The technician is looking for certain levels of hemoglobin in your blood, but they will likely just have a general range to see if you fall above or below certain levels. They'll disqualify you if you fall in these ranges. For instance, if your hemoglobin levels fall below 12.5 g/dL for a woman or 13 g/dL for a man, you can't give blood because your iron levels are likely too low. If your levels are above 20 g/dL for a man or woman, you can't give blood because your iron levels are likely too high. This is a rare occurrence.

steps.title: Notice fatigue or weakness if you suspect low iron levels.
steps.content: Notice fatigue or weakness if you suspect low iron levels. Fatigue is one of the primary signs of low iron levels. Iron is essential to your red blood cells, and your red blood cells carry oxygen throughout your body. When your red blood cells are low, your body isn't getting as much oxygen as it's accustomed to, which can make you feel very tired and weak. [10] X Trustworthy Source National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Research and education center within the National Institutes of Health Go to source Generally, this symptom is more than feeling a little tired for a day or two. It's a deeper tiredness that lasts over time.

steps.title: Pay attention to shortness of breath or dizziness for low iron.
steps.content: Pay attention to shortness of breath or dizziness for low iron. Because your body isn't getting enough oxygen, you may feel dizzy or lightheaded due to lack of oxygen. This can, in extreme circumstances, lead to issues with breathing, such as feeling like you can't take a deep breath. Such symptoms are rare, and typically associated with situations where someone is actively losing blood. [11] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You may also notice headaches, which are a related symptom.

steps.title: Check for coldness in your extremities for low iron.
steps.content: Check for coldness in your extremities for low iron. With low iron levels, your heart is having to work harder to pump blood to your body because it doesn't have as many cells to carry oxygen. Therefore, your fingers and toes may feel colder than normal. [12] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Look in the mirror for pale skin, a symptom of low iron.
steps.content: Look in the mirror for pale skin, a symptom of low iron. With your heart not pumping as efficiently, you may end up with pale skin. You may also notice this symptom in your nail beds and your gums. [13] X Trustworthy Source National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Research and education center within the National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Be vigilant about heart problems with low iron.
steps.content: Be vigilant about heart problems with low iron. Because your heart is working harder to move blood through your body, you can end up with heart problems. For instance, you may have a heart arrhythmia or murmur, which can feel like your heart is skipping a beat. [14] X Trustworthy Source National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Research and education center within the National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Notice if you get odd cravings for non-food items for low iron.
steps.content: Notice if you get odd cravings for non-food items for low iron. Your body knows it's deficient in a needed nutrient, iron, and it may come up with odd cravings for things that aren't food. For instance, you may crave dirt, ice, or starch. [15] X Trustworthy Source National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Research and education center within the National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Watch for stomach issues, as they could indicate high iron levels.
steps.content: Watch for stomach issues, as they could indicate high iron levels. The main symptoms of high iron have to do with your stomach. You may experience constipation, vomiting, nausea, or stomach pain, all of which could indicate high iron levels. [16] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Stomach issues can be a sign of many diseases, so don't automatically assume these issues are from high iron.
